Issues.Title: [Feature Request] Class flag to disable responsiveness on navbar (links always show, no hamburger).
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma** and is a **feature request**.

### Description

**Use case:** Electron app using Vue2 and Bulma.

What I'm wanting is something like a class that tells bulma navbar to flat out not be responsive (at least in regard to top-bar links dissappearing for the hamburger.) A split screen forces the user to click the hamburger when the navbar only has a few links. I'm pulling Bulma in to SimulatedGREG's [electron-vue](https://github.com/SimulatedGREG/electron-vue) boilerplate. Then npm installing bulma as a dependency. I'd rather not have to touch the framework just to keep two/three links visible. I know an electron app probably wasn't the original intent of where this would be used, but it's a great fit if you all could support some scenarios like this.

### Steps to Reproduce
1 - Pull down the [electron-vue](https://github.com/SimulatedGREG/electron-vue) boilerplate and `npm i`
2 - Get maybe 2 or 3 routes setup (like for a simple app)
3 - Grab the 1st navbar example from the Bulma site, change the 1st two navbar-item's to router-links
4 - Remove burger and everything else to make it look kinda like below:
```
<template lang='pug'>
#app
    nav.navbar(role="navigation" aria-label="main navigation")
        .navbar-brand
            a.navbar-item(href="https://bulma.io")
                img(src="https://bulma.io/images/bulma-logo.png" width="112" height="28")
        #navbarBasicExample.navbar-menu
            .navbar-start
                router-link(to='/').navbar-item
                    | Menu-Link1
                router-link(to='/something').navbar-item
                    | Menu-Link2
    router-view
</template>

<style lang='scss'>
@import "~bulma/css/bulma.css";
/* CSS */
</style>
```
5 - `npm run dev`

### Expected behavior

If burger html or class like 'disable-responsive' or 'disable-burger' (pick 1, I'm not saying all 3) is added to nav element with 'navbar', the two links will remain. When super small width they can just break as the min-width of the window could be set at the electron level, preventing the user from ever seeing it.

### Actual behavior
Split screen with few views results in unnecessary click by user. Dependency has to be tweaked. #1042 doesn't really hit the mark here since it is more involved and Bulma is already a great fit stock for small apps.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Feature Request] Class flag to disable responsiveness on navbar (links always show, no hamburger)." (#2391)

Issues.Title: Style :invalid pseudo-class
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description

Would it make sense for Bulma to style input elements using the `:invalid` pseudo-class?

Say we have an `<input type="email">`. If we don't enter an email address into the field, most browsers will add the `:invalid` pseudo-class to the element and display a tooltip error, looking something like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/204153/53570245-eca8e600-3b5d-11e9-9cfc-31c9142a2289.png)

If we end up clicking somewhere else on the page though, most browsers will dismiss that tooltip and we just get this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/204153/53570278-05b19700-3b5e-11e9-98bb-37c88e3b90a7.png)

I feel like it would make more sense if Bulma's SASS allowed this to match the `is-danger` class:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/204153/53570347-2aa60a00-3b5e-11e9-92c7-49586ce40c2c.png)

---

Obviously, this is no replacement for server-side validation of your forms. That said, I feel like it would make for a nicer UX, and I feel like adding this probably wouldn't result in much extra SASS.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Style :invalid pseudo-class" (#2384)

This is a **bugfix**.

### Proposed solution
#### Issue
When you have long buttons within **.buttons** and **.is-centered** and a button moves to a lower line the alignment of each button is off.

Add equal margin to both sides of the button.

### Tradeoffs
We are using button margin value of **0.5rem** (**0.25rem** each side for **.is-centered**) that value could change so it might be beneficial to use a variable here instead.

Issues.Title: Feature discussion: object-fit
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

 This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.7.4]
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**?

### Description

I'm gonna work on it, this is just an RFC.
I want to implement `object-fit` for `.image`.
 It can be supported for more elements (e.g. `video`) as well although edge doesn't support any elements but `img` for now. (it's gonna use chromium soon so that shouldn't be a problem.)

[CANIUSE](https://caniuse.com/#feat=object-fit)

### Suggested Classes

I suggest using `.is-cover` for `object-fit: cover`, `.is-contain`, and `.is-fill` (the last one is the default behavior so I find it unnecessary) .
I also want to support `object-position` that has similar values to `background-position`.
I suggest using `.is-centered`, `.is-top`, `.is-bottom`, `.is-left`, `.is-right` (center is the default behavior)

I'm happy to receive feedback to reach the best possible result.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Feature discussion: object-fit" (#2377)
